author: https://lemmy.world/u/ampersandrew
title: EA has open sourced a bunch of old Command & Conquer games
text:
I’m not well versed in C&C, but it’s always good to see more games open sourced.
log in or registerto comment.
To use the compiled binaries, you must own the game
Was expecting a catch. Still good for modding I guess
Anyone know if this is a technologically-enforced “must” or just a “pretty please”?
Open source does not mean that the intellectual property is free. There’s a lot of good that comes from this, and it’s not like those games are expensive.
Though do also note that of these four, TD and RA1 were already made freeware years ago.
I realize. Intellectual property is an icky concept IMO but I know not everyone agrees
Intellectual property is what allows them to make these games GPL.
The entire series is on sale on Steam right now for $6 if that helps.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1213210/Command__Conquer_Remastered_Collection/That’s only the HD remaster of TD and RA1.
It’s about thyme!
No matter what you think of EA, this is fantastic news.
Perhaps why this feels like them trying to save face.
This feels more like some o.g. Command and conquer devs who have worked at EA for a long time that are passionate about the franchise. There was no big PR release, no product tie in or announcement, no media campaign.
Recovering and restoring the source code for these titles was made possible through the combined efforts of EA technical director Brian Barnes, Respawn producer Jim Vessella, and Luke Feenan, a long-standing member of the C&C community who was involved in the development of the Command & Conquer Remastered Collection.
https://www.polygon.com/news/531365/command-and-conquer-open-source-code-eaAh well I’m glad to see the devs sticking to their passions. I’m sure they’re proud of this move.
With that said, I’m still surprised EA didn’t try to capitalize on it somehow.
On what?
Just in general. EA has a lot to around for.
Extremely rare EA win
Open sourcing old games is awesome for video game preservation.
Fuck EA but cool move - if they keep being not shit for long enough I might consider their products again.
Doubt they can keep it up.
Old games being open sourced is a trend I can get behind.
I’m ready for a zero hour remake!
Im now just happy that it’s far more likely for a clean 60fps mod that’s not locked behind someone’s patreon
It’s a kick ass game but some of the tropes didn’t age well.
Ak47s for everyone!
Can I at least have some shoes?
EA ? Did I read right ?
Mmmmm pre-standard C++
RENEGADE!!!
Loved Renegade so much. Played the shit out of the MP back in the day.
That game seemed so underappreciated. I would be thrilled if I could have another LAN party with it.
Well I’m very excited to see the injection of life this hopefully gives c&c modding
I wonder how many of the old guard are still around, I’m glad the cncnet project is still going strong
They’re still requiring EA Play or $6 for the bundle on steam.
Correct. Doom and Quake still cost money as well.
topics: Science and Technology->information technology and computer science

author: Penetrator
title: #55 Reino Unido no recuperará las onzas y las libras como medidas: un 98,7% de los británicos están en contra
text:
Portada
mis comunidades
otras secciones
[#2](c2#c-2) Pasa eso porque los medios privados son exclusivamente de derechas, como buena propiedad de multimillonarios que son.
Y dejarán de usar electricidad para pasar a máquinas de vapor. Puestos a ir para atrás que al menos monten un parque de atracciones steampunk para que los demás podamos ir de turismo.
[#8](c8#c-8) Luditas: artesanos contra la Revolución Industrial
https://www.muyinteresante.es/historia/59901.html
Ya solo les queda abandonar las millas, las yardas, los pies y las pulgadas y descubrir lo práctico que es el sistema métrico decimal también para longitudes. Que lo de que una pulgada se convierte de 2,54cms, un pie son 12 pulgadas y una yarda 3 pies es algo maravillosamente caótico pero completamente ineficiente.
No termino de entender eso de mezclar nacionalismo con ciencia. Sería maravillosamente distópico que en España siguiésemos usando números romanos en matemáticas porque los otros no nos son tan "naturales".
Se han acostumbrado a lo razonable y nadie quiere volver atrás.
Realmente harían muy bien en medir las distancias en metros y dejarse de chorradas.
Por cierto, que no es algo muy sabido pero los paises con unidades raras en realidad son miembros del sistema métrico internacional. Así pues un foot tiene de largo 0.3048m exactamente (no hay más decimales pues ésta es la definición)
O lo que dice
[#7](c7#c-7) , que da otro número exacto.
[#15](c15#c-15) Todas sus medidas tienen su conversión a sistema métrico, pero sigue siendo un cachondeo, porque una es más o menos 2,5 y la siguiente que tienen ya pasa a 30. Además, es muy gracioso el ver lo imprecisas que son muchas de las mediciones que usan. Lo mítico es que la altura de las personas la midan en pies y pulgadas: un pie son 30,48cm y una pulgada 2,54cm, con lo que para americanos y británicos 1,72, 1,73 y 1,74 pueden terminar siendo el mismo número (5 pies y 8 pulgadas), con lo que los ves redondeando todo el rato o inventándose cosas como la media pulgada para ser un poco más claros.
[#16](c16#c-16) luego los americanos son otros que ya tal.. porque aparte de las imperiales tienen sus propias medidas autóctonas, como las de volumen que una onza puede ser diferente si hablan de líquidos diferentes y más cosas
[#15](c15#c-15) Por supuesto que nadie quiere volver atrás. Es que sólo a un subnormal del culo como Boris Johnson se le podía ocurrir la brillante idea de volver a semejante mierda de sistema.
[#7](c7#c-7) las yardas hace décadas que nadie las usa, y las pulgadas sólo se usan para cosas puntuales, más por tradición que otra cosa.
Los pies lo mismo, sólo se usan en cosas muy puntuales, pero igual que los usamos nosotros, con los contenedores marítimos de 20 y 40 pies, y algunos tipos de tubería los medimos en pulgadas
[#17](c17#c-17) Aguantan más de lo que parece, porque si te paras a pensar la pantalla de los televisiones, monitores y móviles se miden en pulgadas, incluso aquí. Y muchos de los muebles que he visto que vienen de fuera también aparecen en páginas como el Amazon americano con medida en pulgadas y el peso en libras. Y las señales americanas si no me equivoco ponen la distancia en millas, y siempre me ha hecho gracia ver cosas como que una milla son 1760 yardas y 5280 pies porque es difícil de recordar.
Yo siempre lo he visto como un atraso, porque no ofrecen nada más allá de la tradición. En pocas semanas cualquiera se acostumbra a leer que su móvil tiene una pantalla de 15cm y que su tele es de 127 y no le causa ningún trauma.
[#32](c32#c-32) sí eso sí, pero las pulgadas de la tele y demás nos las comemos por los EEUU, el problema de los americanos es que son muy "especialitos" y la mayoría no quiere reconocer que algo de afuera es mejor que lo suyo.
[#18](c18#c-18) En el caso de norteamerica creo recordar q tenia cierta relevancia. Cuando hicieron la parcelacion del pais usaron esas metricas y pasar el sistema decimal podria llevar a disputas territoriales algo que en un pais donde hay mas armas que personas emmm...
[#18](c18#c-18) Y nunca he visto dos pantallas de 15 pulgadas que midan lo mismo.
Supuestamente era el tamaño del tubo antes de meterlo en chasis, pero más bien es una categoría de tamaño.
Igual que nos contenedores internodales. Los hay normales o del doble de longitud. Y nada más. Que tradicionalmente se miran en pues pues es tradicion, al igual que las velocidades de las embarcaciones en nudos.
Justo lo estaba leyendo hace un rato:
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/dec/27/pint-of-wine-anyone-uk-looks-to-bring-back-silly-measure
Lo importante es que ahora podraá vender el vino en botellas de una pinta (si quisieran y alguien tuviera interés, que parece ser que no)
[#50](c50#c-50) Claro, "dame dos pounds de eso" es "dame dos libras de eso", o sea, le das una moneda de 2 pounds por ello.
Pero las onzas?
En cualquier caso no es algo que viera habitualmente. En USA usan las onzas hasta para la marihuana. No sé si en algún sitio de UK lo harán también así.
https://www.royalqueenseeds.es/blog-cantidades-de-cannabis-gramo-octavo-cuarto-y-onza-n1199
Yo aquí me pierdo algo. Juraría que en la pérfida albión se sigue pesando en libras, galones, se pesa el body en piedras, las distancias en millas yardas y piés, y demás cosas raras que hacen los british. ¡Si hasta siguen conduciendo por la izquierda!. Y solo hace dos meses de nuestra última visita por aquellos lares.
[#9](c9#c-9) No es en USA donde se hace así?
Lo de las millas sí que se hace en ambos sitios, pero lo de las onzas, etc, yo diría que es en USA.
[#9](c9#c-9) Lo curioso es que el origen de conducir por la izquierda puede remontarse a la invencion de la espada y conducir por la derecha tiene origenes peyorativos;
https://blog.terranea.es/por-que-se-conduce-por-la-izquierda/
[#9](c9#c-9) no, los British tienen un sistema raro. El peso se usa kg, las distancias se hacen en millas y la capacidad en litros o pintas dependiendo de a quien preguntes.

author: CKOM News
title: Prairie Harm Reduction, Health Ministry issue new illicit drug alert for Saskatoon area
text:
The Saskatchewan health ministry and Prairie Harm Reduction (PHR) have issued a new drug alert for Saskatoon and surrounding areas, including the R.M. of Blucher, Corman Park, Warman, Martensville, Dundurn, Aberdeen and Vanscoy.
According to recent testing done by PHR, the drug in question is sold as fentanyl, but actually contains parafluorofentanyl, which can be more potent.
Read more:
According to PHR’s social media post on July 2, the drug also contains other potentially deadly ingredients, including benzodiazepines and xylazine.
“When paraflurofentanyl is mixed with xylazine (a veterinary tranquillizer) and benzodiazepine (like clonazapam or alprazolam), the combination creates a highly toxic and dangerous cocktail.
“Each of these substances on their own is dangerous. Together they significantly increase the risk of fatal overdose, especially through respiratory depression,” it read.
The material looks like purple chunks and is smoked.
In an alert sent out on July 2, 2025, the drug in question was described as purple chunks and is being sold as fentanyl. (Saskatchewan Ministry of Health)
PHR said Xylazine’s risks alone include severe hypotension (slow heart rate) and loss of blood flow to tissues. Long-term use can cause “necrotic skin ulcers.”
The health ministry and PHR advise that naloxone can reverse the effects of the opioids in the drug, but will not have any effect on the mixed drugs.
Despite naloxone having no impact on the mixed drugs’ effects, it’s still advised to use naloxone in the case of an overdose, as it can restore breathing.
topics: Crime, Law and Justice->drug related crimes

author: BuzzFeed
title: Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence
text:
Reuters Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence Read full article 1 / 5 Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence A Palestinian bride adjusts her veil in a tent camp on her wedding day in Rafah 2 / 5 Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence A Palestinian couple stands in a tent camp on their wedding day in Rafah 3 / 5 Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence A Palestinian couple walks on their wedding day in the tent camp in Rafah Yahoo News is better in the app Stay in the know at a glance with the Top 10 daily stories
4 / 5 Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence A Palestinian couple greets guests in a tent camp on their wedding day in Rafah 5 / 5 Gaza couple marry in tent city by barbed wire border fence A Palestinian couple walks on their wedding day in the tent camp in Rafah Mohammad Salem January 19, 2024 at 7:20 p.m. · 3 min read
By Mohammad Salem
RAFAH, Gaza (Reuters) - Palestinian groom Mohammed al-Ghandour wanted to give his bride a beautiful wedding but after war began in Gaza they had to flee their homes and the couple finally got married this week in the tent city where they now live.
Ghandour led his wife Shahad by the hand towards the tent decorated with some coloured lights and a mirror with a gold-coloured frame as a few relatives escorted them, clapping in time.
Inside the tent Shahad, wearing a white dress and veil with traditional red embroidery, lifted her hand and Ghandour put a ring on it.
"I wanted a party. I wanted a celebration, a wedding. I wanted to invite my friends, my relatives and my cousins, like anyone would," said Ghandour.
The couple are from Gaza City in the north of the tiny enclave where some of the worst of Israel's heavy bombardment and the fighting between it and Hamas have taken place since the war began on Oct. 7.
The homes of both Ghandour's family and Shahad's family were destroyed in Israeli airstrikes, they said, and they lost cousins and other family members in the bombardment.
"My happiness is maybe at 3% but will get myself ready for my wife. I want to make her happy," said Ghandour.
The war began when Hamas fighters rampaged into Israel, killing more than 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking 240 hostages. Israel's bombardment and assault into Gaza have killed more than 24,760 people according to health authorities there.
Instead of the big party that Ghandour had wanted, he and Shahad had a small group of relatives who like them had managed to leave Gaza City and flee to Rafah, at the far southern end of the strip next to Egypt.
Shahad's mother led a small group of women ululating in celebration of the marriage and somebody had saved batteries for a small portable music player.
For a wedding feast in an enclave that the U.N. warns is heading towards famine, the couple had only a few snacks in plastic package, laid out carefully for them in the tent.
Story continues Both families had already spent lots of money on the wedding before the war began. Shahad had spent more than $2,000 on clothes, they said.
"My dream was to give Shahad the best wedding, the most beautiful in the world," said her mother, Umm Yahia Khalifa.
"We prepared her wedding things and she was happy. But it is all gone in the shelling. Every time she remembers she starts to cry," she said.
As the small wedding party began to clap and dance, people around them went about their daily chores among the lines of tents stretched across the sand, seeking food or hanging laundry.
A small girl in a pink and white dress smiled broadly as the clapping began and joined a group of other children dancing as the sun set behind the high border fence topped with barbed wire.
(Reporting by Mohammad Salem, writing by Angus McDowall; Editing by Toby Chopra)

Families of missing people in Dawson Creek, B.C., fear the worst as gang violence spikes
